 1. ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES A. Background 1. Trinidad and Tobago, with a total land area of 5,128 sq km, is located at the southern end of the West Indian archipelago. Trinidad, the larger island is 4,820 sq km in area and is within sight of the east coast of Venezuela. The island's topography is dominated by three parallel ranges of hills. The Northern Range, a rugged outlier of the Eastern Cordillera of the Andes, the Central Range and the Trinity Hills in the south. Three major river systems separate the ranges of hills, forming broad plains, two draining westward into the Gulf of Paria (which separates Trinidad from Venezuela), and one draining eastward into the Atlantic Ocean. Tobago lies 32 km northeast of Trinidad and is 303 sq km in area. The island is dominated by the Main Ridge of hills, which are most rugged in the north. 2. Trinidad and Tobago's climate is tropical with a unimodal rainfall pattern which results in two distinct seasons: a wet season from the end of May to December and a dry season from January to April. As a result of prevailing winds, rainfall is higher in the north-east quadrants of both islands. Average annual rainfall ranges from 2,880 mm in the east to 1,200 mm in the west. Trinidad, lying just south of the "hurricane belt", has not experienced a severe tropical cyclone in recorded history. Tobago is less fortunate and was seriously damaged by hurricane Flora in 1963. 3. The nation's ethnically diverse population, totalling 1.23 million in 1990, is dominated by the descendants of people transported from Africa, India and other parts of the world to labor on the plantations during the colonial era (the indigenous Amerindian population became extinct during the last century). Population growth-rate peaked at 1.7 percent per annum in 1985 and fell to 0.8 percent in 1990, due mainly to emigration. The capital city, Port of Spain, has a population of some 80,000. Approximately three-quarters of the population are urban dwellers, most inhabiting two conurbations -- the Port of Spain-Arima corridor and the Port of Spain-San Fernando corridor. 4. Petroleum quickly replaced agriculture as the mainstay of the economy following the discovery of oil early this century -- Trinidad's oil was an important resource to the Allies during WWII. Industrialization soon followed, bringing increasing economic prosperity to the nation. As a result of major oil and natural gas finds, the GNP per capita increased from US$960 in 1972 to over US$6,600 in 1982 but domestic policies of the time failed to harness the windfall, and the subsequent fall in international oil prices, coupled with declining national oil production, resulted in contraction of the economy. In spite of improved economic policies, there has been little economic growth in recent years, and estimates put the 1993 GNP per capita at around US$3,250. A decade of economic depression, and structural adjustment has contributed to increased unemployment (20 percent in 1993), and many people have migrated, mainly to North America, to seek employment.
 2 B. Pollution 5. Trinidad and Tobago's major exports include petroleum products, ammonia, iron and steel, fertilizers, methanol, chemicals, and sugar -- all potentially polluting industries. Inasmuch as environmental protection was not an integral part of the Government's industrialization policy, and without effluent and emissions standards, there was no incentive for industry to introduce the newer and cleaner technologies being introduced in countries where pollution control was being enforced. Exceptions were industries involving foreign joint-venture partners which adopted 'headquarters' standards. Until recently, pollution has gone on virtually uncontrolled. This situation has resulted in a number of environmental reviews which generally concluded that the major pollution issues center upon industrial and urban effluents -- mainly liquid and gases, solid and hazardous wastes, and pollution resulting from destruction of forests in the upper watersheds. Recently, lead and noise have been added to the list. Trinidad is more threatened by industrial pollution than Tobago, where increasing volumes of sewage from the developing tourist industry (the island's major economic activity) is beginning to pose a threat. (a) Pollution of Water Resources with pollutants stemming from industry is debatably the most important issue. Examples include untreated, or partially treated liquid effluent from oil and petrochemical installations, breweries and alcohol distilleries, sugar refineries, canning and packaging plants; agriculture -- pesticide, herbicide and fertilizer run-off from agricultural lands, animal and other organic wastes; urban areas -- detergents, sanitary waste and raw and incompletely processed sewage; and activities in the upper watersheds -- logging, forest clearing, agricultural activities, and quarrying causing soil erosion and siltation of waterways; and mining -- suspended solids from sand and gravel pits. These pollutants enter streams, rivers and wetland areas and, in some cases, percolate into ground water. (b) Solid Waste, stemming from industry and urban sources comprising paper, plastic, metal, glass, vegetable and food waste, has been identified as a priority issue. Whereas some recycling is practiced, current policy is to dispose of the bulk of solid waste in landfills. Issues include the prompt collection of waste, its method of transportation and disposal at the landfills, and the possible effects of leachate, and smoke and gases from fires at the landfill sites. Little is known about the environmental impact of the landfills. (c) Hazardous Wastes are, in general, disposed of in the same way as other solid and liquid wastes -- into the landfills or the waterways. Humans, birds and animals routinely sift the contents of the landfills for items of value and are constantly exposed to hospital waste, heavy metals and noxious and poisonous chemicals.
 3 (d) Air Pollution is becoming an increasingly important issue as industrialization and urbanization increases. Industrial sources of air pollution include gases and particulate emissions created during the refining of petroleum products; the smelting of iron, steel and lead; the manufacture of ammonia, cement, and the transhipping of bauxite from Guyana. Agricultural sources of air pollution include smoke and ash from sugar cane and bagasse burning, and land clearing activities. Gaseous and particulate emissions from vehicles are another source of air pollution in urban areas -- the majority of vehicles use leaded gasoline, and catalytic converters are currently not required. (e) Noise Pollution, especially on industrial sites and in urban areas, has been an issue for many years, but its economic impact has not been quantified. C Natural Resources Degradation 6. Overview of the Natural Resources of Trinidad and Tobago (a) Land in Trinidad and Tobago is classified on the basis of agricultural suitability; fertile land suitable for the production of most tropical crops (16 percent), (located primarily in the lower valleys and flood plains of major river basins), land which is less suitable for agriculture because of low fertility and inadequate drainage (46 percent), (including the clay soils of central and southern Trinidad), and land with little or no agricultural value (38 percent), (mainly poor, erosion-prone soils on hillsides, and waterlogged soils in the estuarine wetlands). (b) Water. Rainfall provides 7.7 billion m3 of fresh water per year. The scarcity of good aquifers in both islands results in heavy reliance on surface water for potable and industrial uses - 70 percent of the nation's water is drawn from rivers and reservoirs. Trinidad has two water-storage dams and two river off-take facilities. Tobago has one of each type of facility. Estimates indicate that current rates of withdrawal of water from rivers and ground-water reserves (90 million m3 per year) are well within the limits of resource availability. (c) Vegetation. Before man modified the landscape, the islands were almost entirely forested. Today seven types of natural forest still occur, from the mangrove forest of the coastal wetlands to the montane forest at the highest elevations of the Northern Range. Although much of the natural forest has been cleared for agricultural, residential and industrial development, 60 percent of the country (307,500 ha) remains forested - although little of it remains undisturbed. The State owns over 80 percent of the forest, nearly one third of which is preserved with the intention of improving water catchment and reducing soil erosion. A significant part of the non-agricultural land in Trinidad is wetland -- including three large estuarine and two inland wetlands (natural areas of grass and shrubs which are inundated during the rainy season).
 4 (d) Biodiversity. The wide range of ecological types has resulted in Trinidad and Tobago being richly endowed with fauna and flora. Over 100 species of mammals, 420 species of birds, 70 species of reptiles, 26 species of amphibians and 76 species of fresh-water fish have been reported. Over 600 species of butterflies have been described, but the list of insect fauna is still incomplete. The islands' flora is similarly diverse, and 2,300 species of flowering plants have been described to date - 86 unique to Trinidad and Tobago. Over 200 species of orchids, 200 species of ferns, 58 species of bromeliads and 34 species of aroids are recorded. Many more species of flora await identification and classification. (e) Coastal and Marine Resources. Trinidad and Tobago's Exclusive Economic Zone is 15 times larger than its land area, and is economically vital to the nation's interests as some 80 percent of its oil is obtained offshore. Marine conditions are strongly influenced by the huge volume of freshwater which enters the sea from the Orinoco Delta, reducing the salinity of coastal waters, and carries sediments which create turbidity and prevent the development of coral in the waters around Trinidad. The nation's 700 km coastline comprises scenic cliffs, sandy beaches, and wetlands - the base for a substantial fishing industry, as well as supporting recreational and tourist activity. On Trinidad, the three major rivers have created estuarine wetlands where their waters meet the sea. Tobago has a number of smaller, ecologically important, wetlands. 7. Natural Resources Management Issues. The islands were initially exploited for their agricultural potential, and during the 18th and 19th Centuries cocoa, sugar and cotton were the dominant crops, mainly produced under the plantation system. Later, citrus, coffee, coconuts and tonka beans became important. Most of the better soils of the plains, undulating hills and foothills of the western end of the Northern Range were under plantations by the end of the last century. Forests were exploited for their timber for mainly local use, as the hardness of many of the local woods discouraged European importers. When industrialization got under way after the discovery of oil at the turn of the century, on-shore installations, storage and loading facilities and eventually petrochemical refineries were constructed. The availability of oil and natural gas soon attracted metal and chemical industries, and together with the rapid urbanization of the country during the "oil-boom" of the 1970s and 80s, the stage was set for the rapid deterioration of the nation's renewable natural resources. Important natural resources management issues include the following: (a) Soil and Water Conservation. The deforestation of hillsides through logging, land clearing for agriculture, quarrying, and property development has resulted in soil erosion, leaving large areas of barren hillsides which are unable to retain rainfall, resulting in flash floods, injuries and loss of life and property damage. The burden of suspended solids in the rivers clog the filters of the water pumps of the Water and Sewerage Authority (responsible for providing the nation's water supply), adding significantly to the agency's operating costs, and reducing the quality of the water.
 5 (b) Loss of Ecosystems and Biodiversity. The destruction of ecosystems caused by agricultural, industrial, and urban development has put many species of plants and animals under threat of extinction. In common with other countries, Trinidad and Tobago traditionally regarded wetlands as waste-areas, suitable for industrial development, and one of the nation's major landfills is located on the margins of the Caroni Swamp, a major wetland -- which includes a nature reserve that Government plans to establish as a national park. The actions of many of the inhabitants of the country have seriously impacted on the nationl's biodiversity. Sea-turtles were traditionally regarded as a free source of meat, and the animals were killed indiscriminately as they came on to the beaches to lay their eggs. Hunters shot and trapped the large mammals and birds of the forest for the much prized game meat -- often disregarding close-seasons, and setting trap-guns which kill and maim indiscriminately. Tiny song-birds were captured for sale to local and overseas caged-bird enthusiasts. River pollution has reduced the populations of fish, amphibians and mammals (e.g the maniatee) in the nation's streams, rivers, wetlands, and coastal waters. The famous Buccoo marine reef off the coast of Tobago has been seriously damaged by human activity -- particularly boat operators. Facilities for the proper treatment of sewage and other liquid effluent from the increasing number of hotels on the coast adjacent to the reef are inadequate, further endangering the reef. (c) Sand Mining. In Tobago, the construction industry has traditionally used beach-sand. With the recent expansion in tourism infrastructure it has been suggested the rate of usage is exceeding the rate of natural replenishment, with the real danger of depleting a valuable tourism resource. With the likelihood of additional hotels, holiday apartments and infrastructure it is foreseeable that the construction industry may erode the very beaches which attract the tourists. D. Legal and Institutionial Background 8. In the past, there has been no integrated approach to the management of the environment in Trinidad and Tobago, the concept being more associated with conservation of wildlife and nature preservation than with pollution control. However recent governments have become increasingly aware of environmental issues, sensitized initially by the UN Conference on the Human Environment (Stockholm 1972). Since that time successive governments have attempted to formulate environmental policy, enact environmental legislation and design systems to manage the environment. Environmental Protection Bills were drafted in 1976 and 1989, but were never brought to Parliament. 9. As environmental issues became of increasing importance, institutional responsibilities for environmental management changed. Following the Stockholm Conference, an Institute for Marine Affairs was established with some environmental responsibilities, (mainly involving collection, analysis and dissemination of information). During the 1970s, responsibility for the environment was switched back and forth between the Ministries of Agriculture and Health until, in 1981, the latter became the Ministry of Health
 6 and the Environment: the first time that the word "Environment" achieved such a high profile. National consultations, studies and reports carried out by PAHO (1987, 1991), the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean (ECLAC) in conjunction with UNEP (1988), and IDB (1992), urged GoRIT to create a specialized agency to manage the nation's environment. Successive governments responded in various ways, by appointing committees, holding consultations etc., and in 1989, the government of the day took the major step of establishing the Ministry of Environment and National Service, transferring the Environmental Management and Forestry Divisions from the Ministry of Food Production and Marine Exploitation. A change of government in 1991 brought a strong commitment to improve environmental management, consistent with an election pledge. The Ministry of the Environment and National Service of the previous government was disbanded and the environmental portfolio transferred to the MoPaD, to integrate environmental management with the planning and development portfolio, thereby giving the environmental agenda greater leverage and focus. As part of this process, MoPaD's Town and Country Planning Division was made responsible for environmental impact assessment'. The new Government took advantage of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (Rio de Janeiro - June 1992), as an opportunity to present its National Report on Environment and Development in which it gave an undertaking to develop a new legal and institutional framework for the management of the nation's environment. 2. THE PROJECT A. Project Objectives and Brief Description Current Program of Reforms in the Policy, Legal and Institutionial Framework for Environmental Management 10. The Government has embarked upon a comprehensive overhaul of the policy, legal and institutional framework for environmental management. The Minister of Planning and Development is currently responsible for the environmental portfolio. In addition to the Ministry of Planning and Development, 27 other government agencies are involved in environment- related activities (see Annex C), acting largely in a policy vacuum and without central coordination. Recognizing both of these drawbacks, MoPaD, using funds from the World Bank Technical Assistance Loan, engaged a consultant in 1992 to coordinate the establishment of a specialized agency for the management of the nation's environment. The decision to create an agency outside of the ministerial structure was taken for a number of reasons, including greater flexibility in procurement and recruitment regulations and 1. This institutional arrangement also provides for a greater degree of involvement of environmental stakeholders outside of government (including the private sector and the NGOs). 11. After meeting stakeholders and reviewing relevant reports, the consultant prepared a Policy Brief which provided profiles on the current situation vis a vis environmental management and legislation, recommended an interim environmental policy, and identified the steps necessary to establish the environmental agency as a statutory body. The document emphasized the need for new legislation to establish the new agency, outlined a management framework and recommended an action plan to bring all of this into being. The Policy Brief was submitted to Cabinet in March 1993, which adopted its recommendations, and directed that legislation be drafted to create an agency to be known as the Environmental Management Authority (EMA). Shortly after, work began on drafting the Environmental Management Act with the assistance of a UNDP consultant. 12. To address the lack of a national environmental policy the Policy Brief recommended that Government adopt a "mission statement" as an interim policy before empowering the proposed EMA to formulate a national environmental policy. Cabinet accepted this recommendation. The Environmental Management Act makes provision for the proposed EMA to play a major role in the preparation of environmental policy for government's consideration and enactment. A Policy Letter (Annex B) clarifies GoRTT's long term policy objectives for the environment. 13. Currently, there are approximately 40 pieces of legislation that have relevance to environmental management. Many of these overlap resulting in conflicting responsibilities among agencies, and much of the legislation is in need of redrafting. It is Government's intention to resolve this unsatisfactory situation and the Environmental Management Act makes specific provision for the EMA to take responsibility for reviewing, updating and where necessary preparing new legislation. 14. The draft Environmental Management Bill was circulated by Government for public comment during August and September 1994. Seventy five written comments were received. After revising the draft to incorporate many of the suggestions resulting from the public review process, and after obtaining the clearance of the Legislative Review Committee, the final draft was tabled before Parliament on December 20, 1994. After debates in the Senate and later the Lower House, the Bill was finally passed with some amendments on February 21, 1995. 15. Project Objectives. In support of Government's environmental policy, the proposed Environmental Management Project has two main objectives:

Operationalization of the Environmental Management Authority (US$3.12 million over four years). The proposed project would finance the start up costs and support the cost of operating the new Environmental Management Authority during the project period. The Borrower gave assurances at negotiations that the EMA would be established with a Board of Directors and a Chief Executive Officer appointed as condition of loan effectiveness, and would thereafter maintain the Agency with responsibilities, functions, structure, funds, facilities, management and staff, satisfactory to the Bank. 20. The Environmental Management Act provides for an 11 person Board of Directors to govern the EMA. The Board will be appointed by the President of Trinidad and Tobago, acting on the advice of the Cabinet of Ministers, and will be accountable to the Minister responsible for the environment (currently the Minister of Planning and Development). The Board, to be appointed by April 30, 1995, will be multidisciplinary and members will be drawn from a wide cross section of disciplines and groups, including environmental management, ecology, environmental health, engineering, labor, community-based organizations, business, economics, public administration, law and non-governmental organizations. The Board is responsible for formulating EMA policy, and the Chief Executive Officer will be responsible for its implementation. The Authority is permitted to set up committees, working groups and advisory councils to assist it to carry out its statutory functions and responsibilities. By these means, wide involvement of diverse groups in the operations of the Authority will be facilitated.

The broad functions of the Environmental Management Authority, as set out in Section 16 (1) of the Environmental Management Act (1995), are: * recommend national environmental policies; * develop and implement policies and programs for the effective management and wise use of the environment; * coordinate environmental management functions; * recommend ways to rationalize the environmental management system to increase efficiency and achieve economies where possible; * promote public awareness; * set national environmental standards and criteria; monitor compliance and take enforcement action; prevent and control pollution and foster conservation of the environment; and establish and coordinate linkages at local, regional and international levels. 22. The EMA's operating system and structure will be articulated by the Board of Directors and executive management, once these are in place. However, an indicative organizational structure has been developed and approved by Government for the purposes of starting up the new Authority. The day-to-day tasks of the EMA would be the subject of an Operations Manual (financed by UNDP) to be compiled under the supervision of the incoming management of the EMA (outline provided in Annex F). The interim organizational structure for the agency comprises: * The Chief Executive's Office -- staffed by the Managing Director (responsible to the Board of Directors for the operation of the EMA) and support staff. * Administration Unit -- responsible for personnel matters, procurement, financial control, and general office administration. Staff would include an Administrative Officer, Procurement Assistant, Book-keeper, Driver/Mechanic and support staff. * Information and Education Unit -- responsible for obtaining, maintaining and making available information pertaining to the environmental affairs. The unit would also be responsible for the educational and training activities of the Authority (including

Support to the Participating Agencies. (US$3.51 million over four years). The Government, in its letter of January 27, 1995 has identified the key Participating Agencies (see Annex C), which would receive institutional strengthening support from the project from the outset. The EMA, as soon as it is operational, will draw up and agree a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with each agency, establishing the details of the relationship between the Authority and the agency. The project also includes funds to: procure documents and library equipment; finance the reporting of environmental complaints; prepare State of the Environment Reports; prepare reports required by International Environmental Treaties; and purchase materials and cover expenses required for public awareness campaigns, curriculum development and environmental education activities. Provision is made for the training of EMA staff and Environmental Officers in the Participating Agencies in the form of both short
 14 and long term formal training. Further details of the proposed Training and Training-Related Technical Assistance Component, including Terms of Reference for the EMA Training Officer and the Training Adviser, and generic training programs are presented in Annex G. 29. Studies and Planning Exercises (US$0.78 million over four years). The proposed project would support several priority studies which would commence under the supervision of MoPaD and be completed under the supervision of the EMA. These studies would contribute to the environmental knowledge base of Trinidad and Tobago, identify priorities for the EMA's work program and generally improve the efficiency of environmental management in the country. Studies would be carried out with a view to establishing an efficient system for the coordination of environmental management centered on the EMA and the Participating Agencies and to provide a medium term development plan for the EMA. Specifically, the project would support the following studies to be started under MoPaD's supervision and completed under that of the EMA: (a) the preparation of a National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP). The priority work program of the EMA would be developed from the NEAP, (b) a series of Rationalization Studies), to identify possible efficiencies and economies to be gained by reorganizing the institutional framework for environmental management, and to identify the institutional strengthening requirements of the Participating Agencies; and (c) a needs analysis for establishing a National Environmental Information System ("the NEIS Study"). The studies would be carried out by consultants under the EMA's supervision, and the finding and recommendations conveyed to Government for approval and implementation as appropriate. Draft terms of reference for these studies are included in Annex H. 30. Further studies would commence once the EMA has become fully operational, including: (a) the preparation of an inventory of sources of pollutants ("Pollutant Inventory Study"); (b) the preparation of an environmental management database to include all projects with environmental implications in Trinidad and Tobago ("MIS Study"); (c) the design of a public participation campaign, formal and non-formal education on environmental topics, a formal training program and on-the-job-training for agency staff and Environmental Officers ("Training Design Study"); (d) a study to evaluate needs and potential for adopting alternative mediation schemes ("Alternative Mediation Study"); (e) two studies relating to the Polluter Pays Principle (PPP) -- one to demonstrate the use of economic instruments as complements to strict regulatory controls, and the other to show where PPP is relevant to Trinidad and Tobago's circumstances -- ("PPP Incentive Studies"); (f) a study to explore alternative means of financing environmental initiatives ("Innovative Finance Mechanism Study"); and (g) a study to illustrate the use and potential for local application of natural resource and environmental accounting methods, ("NREA Study"). Terms of Reference for these studies are also presented in Annex G.

The Government considers the programme as being of very high priority. This strong commitment reflects, first of all, our concern to put in place an environmental management regime and supporting systems which will ensure that as we continue to develop the country, the growth that takes place is sustainable and consistent with the need for resource conservation and environmental preservation. Additionally, we wish to deal effectively with some of the problems that have arisen from improper environmental management. These include forest destruction (especially in the Northern Range); river pollution; irresponsible quarrying of limestone, gravel and sand; water pollution, particularly in the west coast; soil pollution resulting from indiscriminate use of agricultural chemicals; and improper disposal of liquid and solid wastes. 3. The present administration has deliberately put environmental management high on its policy agenda. In 1992, shortly after taking office, the Government reviewed the existing legal and institutional framework for environmental management. The review revealed serious weaknesses in the legal and institutional framework, including the following:
 36 ANNEX B a) a proliferation of agencies involved, in one way or other, with environmental management issues; b) a lack of formalized mechanisms for co-ordination; c) the fragmentation of legislative instruments, giving rise to jurisdictional difficulties and contributing to complexity and ineffectiveness in enforcement action, and d) gaps in coverage (e.g. noise and air pollution). New Le2islation 4. The review was followed by preparation of a policy brief to be used in developing a new legislative and institutional framework. The policy brief was approved by Cabinet in 1993. Cabinet also approved the adoption of the following mission statement: The Government of Trinidad and Tobago is committed to the concept of sustainable development which is an approach to progress that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their needs. Consequently, the Government shall make provision for the establishment and operation of an environmental management agency for the formulation and execution of national environmental policies and practices, for the promotion of public awareness of environmental concerns, and for the establishment of an effective regulatory regime which will improve, protect and conserve the natural and cultural heritage of the country and avoid environmental damage and degradation of natural resources and secure sustainable development. Against that background, new legislation was drafted during 1994 with the assistance of a legal consultant whose services were made available through the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and UNEP. As a matter of deliberate policy, the Government has placed a great deal of emphasis on securing full public participation in the process of evolving the new legislative and institutional framework. Accordingly, the Environrmental Management Bill was published for public review and comment during August/September 1994. There was strong public interest and the responses were generally constructive and incisive. Following consideration of the comments received, several amendments were made to the draft legislation. The revised Bill was approved by Cabinet on December 15, 1994 and tabled in Parliament on December 20, 1994. Debate on the Bill commenced on January 10, 1995 and the legislation is expected to be approved by February 28, 1995.
 37 ANNEX B Environmental Management Authority 5. Key features of the new legislation include the establishment of an Environmental Management Authority, an Environmental Trust Fund and an Environmental Commission. The broad functions of the Authority are to -- (a) make recommendations for a National Environmental Policy; (b) develop and implement policies and programmes for the effective management and wise use of the environment, consistent with the objects of the Act; (c) co-ordinate environmental management functions performed by persons in Trinidad and Tobago; (d) make recommendations for the rationalisation of all governmental entities performing environmental functions; (e) promote educational and public awareness programmes on the environment; (f) develop and establish national environmental standards and criteria; (g) monitor compliance with the standards, criteria and programmes relating to the environment" (h) take all appropriate actions for the prevention and control of pollution and conservation of the environment; and (i) establish and co-ordinate institutional linkages locally, regionally and internationally. 6. The enabling legislation will give the Authority adequate powers to be an effective instrument for the promotion of sound environmental practices. The specific powers include, for example, the ability to: (a) establish procedures for the registration of sources from which pollutants may be released into the environment and the characterization of such sources; (b) specify the quantity, condition or concentration of pollutants or substances containing pollutants that may be released into the environment, (c) set out procedures and standards with respect to permits or licences required for a person to install or operate any process or other source from which pollutants may be released into the environment;
 38 ANNEX B (d) establish procedures and standards for the formal designation and protection of "environmentally sensitive areas" or "environmentally sensitive species"; (e) introduce incentive programmes or mechanisms which encourage the use of effective environmental systems and the achievement of improvements in environmental quality, (f) designate hazardous substances or categories of hazardous substances, and the performance standards, procedures, safeguards and licensing or permitting requirements in accordance with which such hazardous substances shall be handled; (g) establish procedures to be followed by anyone required to apply for a certificate of environmental clearance, and the standards for preparation and submission of environmental impact assessment; (h) define various categories of waste and the requirements with respect to the handling and disposal of such waste, as well as license facilities at which such wastes are to be handled or disposed; (i) establish procedures and standards for the monitoring of pollutant releases from any process, activity, vehicle or premises; (j) declare ambient environmental quality criteria and standards; and (k) approve the design, construction, operation, maintenance and monitoring of facilities or processes for the control of pollution and the handling of wastes. 7. It is of significance that the legislation provides that the Authority " .... shall facilitate co- operation among persons and manage the environment in a manner which fosters participation and promotes consensus, including the encouragement and use of appropriate means to avoid or expeditiously resolve disputes through mechanisms for alternative dispute resolution." This reflects our conviction that the Authority must not be unduly confrontational or anti-development and that it should seek to engender co-operation, promote awareness and encourage voluntary compliance as key strategies in the pursuit of national environmental management objectives. 8. At the same time, the Authority will be afforded a considerable degree of operating autonomy. It will be set up as a statutory body, governed by a I l-person Board of Directors appointed by the President of the Republic on the advice of the Cabinet. The Board will be accountable to the Minister responsible for Environmental Matters who will give general policy directions to the Authority. The composition of the Board will be multidisciplinary and members will be drawn from a wide cross- section of disciplines and groups, including: environmental management, ecology, environmental health, engineering, labour, community-based organizations, business, economics, public administration, law, and non-governmental organisations (NGOs). The Authority will also be
 39 ANNEX B permitted to set up committees, working groups or advisory councils to assist in carrying out its functions. These devices will allow for wide involvement and mobilization of the national community. Environmental Trust Fund 9. The new legislation also establishes an Environmental Trust Fund which will be used to fund the operations of the Authority and to promote national environmental management objectives. The activities to be supported by the Trust Fund include: (a) incentive measures for reducing environmental pollution, protecting the environment and conserving natural resources; (b) demonstration projects of innovative technologies which reduce pollution, or which reduce or eliminate the use of hazardous substances or the generation of wastes; (c) emergency response activities to address actual or potential threats to human health or the environment, including remediation or restoration of environmentally degraded sites, containment of any wastes, hazardous substances or other environmentally dangerous conditions, or other appropriate precautionary measures to prevent significant adverse effects on human health or the environment; and (d) public awareness and education programmes to enhance the understanding of the environmental protection and natural resources management issues within Trinidad and Tobago. 10. The legislation specifically requires the Authority to prepare recommendations for a comprehensive National Environmental Policy (NEP). The Authority's recommendations must be based on an analysis of the prevailing state of the environment, targeted environmental quality norms, ecological and other balances required to conserve natural resources and protect the environment and consideration of areas of the environment requiring special protection. It is obligatory for the Authority to complete its initial recommendations not later than two years after the Act takes effect. The NEP must also include: (a) provisions to encourage the establishment of institutional linkages locally, regionally and internationally to further the objectives of the Act; (b) analyses of factors impacting upon the development and successful implementation of national environmental policy; and (c) a programme for promoting the policy and building national commitment. Provision is made to facilitate public comment on the policy proposals.
 40 ANNEX B Rationalisation Activitv 11. The Government is convinced that given the inherent constraints the process of strengthening and rationalizing the national environmental management framework must be evolutionary. The programme envisages that the Authority will commence a series of Rationalization Studies not later than six months after it commences operations. The studies will each focus on a particular sub-set of the national environmental management system, either in relation to a priority functional area or a cluster of institutions. The primary objective of the study will be to develop specific recommendations to rationalize the sub-system and enhance capacity and performance. This may include any or all of the following options: (a) merger of existing institutions to improve effectiveness and better utilise scarce resources; (b) consolidation, rationalisation and modernisation of legislation; (c) elimination of duplication of programmes or activities; (d) strengthening of an existing institution; and (e) accessing services from private providers as an alternative to continuing or expanding the services of an existing agency. 12. The second and subsequent phases of this programme will be characterised by the implementation of recommendations generated by the completed studies and the mounting of additional rationalisation studies. Operatine Mechanisms 13. The EMA will use the instrument of delegation to enhance the effectiveness of existina agencies involved in environmental management. Through delegation these agencies will be permitted to exercise some of the powers of the Authority in furtherance of the objectives of the legislation. Thus, the Authority will be required, within three months of the Act coming into effect, to initiate consultation with these agencies to establish mechanisms for co-ordination, implementation of integrated environmental management programmes, the drawing up of memoranda of understanding, and the designation of Environmental Officers. 14. The Government also regards the attainment of cost-effectiveness as an important goal of the programme. This is reflected in the aspect of programme design related to the Authority itself We have avoided a monolithic organisational structure. The Authority will be required to maintain a lean
 41 ANNEX B operation and to contract various services from other government agencies or private sector providers in order to get many of its tasks done without the necessity to include such resources within its staff complement. Examples of this are laboratory services and field operatives. 15. The Government is determined to make the Authority fully operational and effective as early as possible. To this end, the Ministry of Planning and Development will shortly award a contract for the development, inter alia, of a core set of environmental standards. The programme for which we are seeking loan resources from the World Bank also provides for the preparation of a National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP) and the commissioning of a needs assessment study with respect to a National Environmental Information System. 16. Cabinet has also agreed in principle to the establishment of an Environmental Task Force which will effectively be the core of the proposed Board of the Authority. The Task Force will plan for the commencement of operations of the Authority. Its responsibilities will also include the search for a Chief Executive Officer and other key executive staff, and the drawing up of terms of reference for specialist services to be provided by consultants on a short-term basis. 17. Government is committed to implement the programme in accordance with the Action Plan appended. Financin2 Arran2ements 18. It is recognized that in the short- to medium-term, the establishment of the EMA will increase the need for resources to cover start-up and operating expenses, without the benefit of economies that are likely to accrue from institutional rationalisation. As regards 1995, the sum of TT$4.4 million has been budgeted to assist in programme implementation (this includes $3.5 million of grant resources to be provided by the UNDP). Counterpart funds will be provided for successive years of the project as identified in the project financing plan. Appropriations budgeted annually and approved by Parliament will be transferred to the Trust Fund to help defray the operating and capital expenses of the Authority. These resources will be augmented by income generated by payments for services rendered by the Authority, fees for permits, licences, etc. Also going into the Trust Fund will be resources mobilised from multilateral and

Human and financial resource constraints, however, require that systematic priorities be set for addressing the problems, and that a broad consensus be established including the appropriate institutional and policy interventions. Experience elsewhere has indicated that such priority-setting and consensus-building can be addressed effectively within a national environmental planning process the output of which is referred to as the National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP). Purpose: The primary objective of this exercise is to establish, within a consistent framework, the substantial technical environmental priorities within Trinidad and Tobago. These problems might include, for example, land degradation (soil erosion, soil productivity decline, toxic waste pollution, solid waste disposal), water resource degradation (water pollution, groundwater abstraction, marine contamination), renewal resource degradation (fisheries decline, deforestation), or air and noise pollution. Establishment of these relative priorities will assist in the staffing of the EMA and in the conduct of specific interventions (institutional, policy, education, project investments). A second objective of the project is to undertake this analysis with substantial and broad input from all stakeholders to insure that some consensus is achieved regarding appropriate interventions. Implementation: To commence in March 1995; started by MoPaD, and completed by EMA. Thsks: Consultations and workshops; research of secondary information sources; analysis of priorities; generation of a report; and, presentation of findings in a final workshop consisting of senior policy-makers and government functionaries. Specifically, the tasks include: (a) review of past work conducted on the physical, economic and social impacts of various environmental problems; (b) enumeration of environmental problems and their causes within the country; (c) preparation and circulation of a brief background paper describing the problems and suggesting broad principles and criteria for establishing priorities; (d) consultations and workshops with government agencies, the private sector, and NGOs regarding the 12. It is recognized that there is substantial duplication and overlapping of mandates. Additionally, some environmental management needs are incremental to existing capacity. It is foreseen that a major function of the EMA would be to coordinate the responsibilities of a network of implementing institutions, rather than to assume direct control. To facilitate this coordination, it will also be necessary to streamline existing operations and rationalize some of the institutional structures to ensure that environmental management is achieved cost-effectively. In addition, it has been recognized that some of the institutions with important roles to play require strengthening before they can assist the EMA carry out its mandate. This strengthening may take the form of investments in human resources development, (through training or specialized staffing), or other improvements (such as analytical facilities or computing equipment). A budget of US$550,000 has been allocated for such strengthening within the project. Purpose: The primary purpose of these studies is to recommend cost-effective mechanisms for rationalizing the environmental management mandates of all relevant government institutions in Trinidad and Tobago. This rationalization should be based on a relatively broad consensus. A secondary purpose is to identify specific institutional strengthening requirements (in the form of training or investment) in the participating institutions that would play a major role in environmental management activities. Implementation: Study I: Feb 1996; EMA Planning Unit Study II: June 1996; EMA Planning Unit Study Ill< Sept 1996; EMA Planning Unit Approach: Based on the findings and recommendations of the NEAP, priority environmental issues will be selected. The first study will focus on the cluster of institutions whose responsibilities impinge on the environmental issue determined as first priority, e.g. oil pollution of rivers. Subsequent rationalization studies would focus on other environmental issues. The studies would involve consultations and workshops with affected institutions; research of secondary information sources; generation of a report; and, presentation of 13. Each study would involve two stages -- Stage I would focus on defining options and lead up to a workshop involving all stakeholders. The second phase would focus on recommending the implementation arrangements. Specifically, the tasks would include: Stage I (a) identify relevant agencies and prepare a "responsibility matrix" enumerating the current mandate of each agency, highlighting significant gaps or overlaps; (b) prepare a series of feasible rationalization 'options' which reflect differing degrees of rationalization. These could, for example, include: (i) status quo, with relatively few changes; (ii) moderate decentralization, which involves moderate changes from the status quo; (iii) moderate centralization, which involves substantial transfer of some mandates directly to the EMA; or, (iv) full decentralization, which involves complete transfer of all environmental mandates to a single authority; (c) preparation of a paper describing the above options and highlighting current responsibilities; (d) consultation with agencies regarding this brief, and facilitation of a one-day workshop to discuss the best means for proceeding; Stage II (e) analysis of the implications of the various scenarios; (f) selection of a preferred scenario, involving specific recommendations; (g) identification of specific implications for the EMA's mode of operation and interaction with Participating Agencies; (h) identification of specific training and investment priorities in the related agencies, where such agencies require strengthening as a result of the rationalization process. This should also include a 10 year investment plan for such strengthening; (funding is available within the project for this purpose); (i) preparation of a final report summarizing the above; and (j) submission of recommendation to Cabinet for approval to implement recommendations of report. Design and implementation of an appropriate system would minimize the likelihood of undue duplication. Purpose: The primary objective of this exercise is to design an appropriate NEIS network that can be used for sharing environmental information and for assisting in compliance monitoring. Implementation: March 1995; MoPaD/EMA Tasks: The tasks associated with this activity focus on: consultation; research of secondary information sources; and, generation of a report. Specifically, the tasks include: (a) interview members of relevant government ministries, the Tobago House of Assembly, statutory bodies, universities, NGOs, and the private sector to determine their needs for environmental management information; (b) provide an assessment of current capacity within these agencies to generate environmental management information; (c) conduct a 'needs analysis' of environmental information requirements and provide recommendations relating to a NEIS network that would meet foreseen needs. The needs should reflect the priorities forthcoming from the NEAP process; (d) provide recommendations for the role of the EMA in this network; (e) develop a preliminary four year NEIS investment plan that includes the following potential elements: key information priorities; equipment needs the proposed EMA and participating agencies, equipment needs for linkage to external services; (f) provide a cost estimate of this plan; (g) identify specific risks associated with implementing the plan, and recommend mitigating measures; and (h) preparation of final report reflecting the above. Budget: US$20,000 14. Indicatiw and subject to change.
 94 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - DRAFT TERMS OF REFERENCE'5 Pollutant Inventory Study Background: Establishment of enforcement priorities will, ultimately, depend on targeting compliance enforcement to those areas which are the most significant polluters. An inventory of current polluters will be used as a baseline for establishing such priorities. Purpose: The primary objective of this study is to conduct a detailed inventory of major sources of industrial and other pollutants in Trinidad and Tobago. A secondary objective is to provide baseline information for future environmental impact assessment. Implementation: July 1995; EMA Technical Unit. Thsks: The tasks associated with this activity focus on: consultation; research of secondary information sources; and, generation of a report. Specifically, the tasks include: (a) review of current environmental and economic information sources; (b) identification of primary pollutants to be addressed; (c) selection of an appropriate methodology for estimating the extent of pollution by pollutant and source; (d) analysis of data to provide an inventory of pollutants, by source and location. Where point sources are not estimable, a general geographic region appropriate to environmental management (e.g., watershed, coastal strip, etc.) will be selected; and, (e) preparation of final report. Budget: US$85,000 15. Indicative and subject to change.
 95 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - DRAFI TERMS OF REFERENCE'6 Environmental Data Base (MIS) Study Background: The implementation of investments identified by the NEAP, and the implementation of programs being undertaken during the first year of the EMA, will place substantial demands on the management capabilities of the new agency. Purpose: The primary objective of this study is to establish a management information system of all environmental projects in Trinidad and Tobago. The database will be maintained by the EMA and will serve as a management tool for the agency and others. Implementation: Started by MoPaD. To be completed by EMA. Thsks: The tasks associated with this activity focus on: consultation; research of secondary information sources; establishment and installation of an operational database; preparation and delivery of a training session for staff of the EMA; and, generation of documentation. Specifically, the tasks would include: (a) review of existing MIS databases (e.g. UNDP); (b) consultation with GoRTT officials and others associated with the planning and execution of environmental projects; (c) preparation of a needs analysis, highlighting management requirements for an information system; (d) selection of two or three alternative approaches to establishing a database that can meet these needs; (e) analysis of costs, advantages, and disadvantages of the alternatives; (f) preparation of a brief recommendation relating to the recommended MIS approach; (g) upon acceptance of the recommendation, selection of appropriate software for implementing the MIS project database; (h) establishment of the database 'shell' on computer hardware in the EMA; (i) entry of project information for up to five relevant projects into the database; (j) preparation and delivery of a draft operating manual for the MIS database; (k) preparation of a short (half-day) training session to demonstrate the database to agency staff; (1) working closely with agency staff to provide on-the-job training, entry of project information for up to 20 additional relevant projects; (m) supervision (via quality control checks) of subsequent entries and updates for a two month period after installation of the system; and (n) revise and prepare a final operating manual for the MIS database. Budget: US$30,000 16. Indicative and subject to change.
 96 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - DRAFT TERMS OF REFERENCE17 Training Needs and Design Study Background: A key goal of the proposed project is to improve the overall level of environmental education and awareness in Trinidad and Tobago. The project has identified approximately US$1.5 million in specific on-the-job and specialized training initiatives that may be implemented over a four year time horizon. Objectives for the overall training program are threefold: (a) general environmental sensitization for all individuals - including staff of the EMA, Environmental Officers and other staff in the Participating Agencies and the public at large; (b) specific management and technical training for all staff in the EMA and Participating Units; and (c) development of an environmental network by providing numerous opportunities for individuals to interact and form working groups for information sharing in either a formal or informal setting. In addition, the training philosophy should reflect the development of a knowledge-based expert institution that focused on active on-the-job training while staff were implementing the mandate of the EMA. For example, staff should be available to undertake their normal duties at least 85 percent of the time, with the remainder potentially dedicated to formal or other training away from their normal place of work. Purpose: The primary purpose of this exercise is to design in detail a four year investment plan that would improve general environmental skills and awareness in the country. The investment plan would address the following four thematic components: (a) a specialized training program for staff of the EMA and the staff of the participating agencies; (b) a public awareness campaign; (c) formal curriculum development; and (d) non-formal education initiatives. In addition, the study would provide input into: (a) identifying the most effective mechanisms for on-the-job training of agency staff by foreign advisers; (b) formulating an appropriate job description for the Education and Training Officer; and (c) identifying equipment needs for the EMA in the form of classroom facilities, audio-visual vehicles, etc. Implementation: Commencing July 1995: EMA Education Unit. Tasks: The tasks would focus on: research of secondary information sources; consultation; analysis of findings; and, generation of a report. Specifically, (a) reviewing existing training and education programs with a view to identifying resources within GoRTI that may be used or modified for one or more of the thematic training components; (b) preparation and circulation of a brief options paper identifying potential alternative training and public 17. Indicative and subject to change.
 97 ANNEX H Training Needs and Design Study (continued) awareness mechanisms; (c) consultation with relevant agencies inside and outside the government sector regarding the desirability of various mechanisms; (d) analysis of alternatives based on consultations and any other relevant research; (e) formulation of recommendations regarding an appropriate specialized training program for staff of the EMA. The training program should be designed to ensure that staff can still undertake their normal duties. Training may include formal course modules, scholarships, or short term study abroad. Specialized training needs for staff of related environmental agencies should also be identified. The work should also identify equipment needs for classroom facilities within the proposed agency; (f) formulation of a public awareness campaign that will be managed by the Information and Education Unit. The campaign should provide a recommended monthly activity break-down and a monthly budget appropriate for media coverage. The work should also identify equipment requirements; for example, this equipment might include a mobile unit with public education materials; (g) recommendations for adjusting the formal curriculum of primary, secondary, and post-secondary education in Trinidad and Tobago. This may include the introduction of specialized environmental training modules or classes, or the sensitization of existing curricula to environmental issues. The investment plan must identify any incremental training resources that will be required to fulfill these recommendations, as well as any institutional changes that may be needed to implement them; (h) formulation of appropriate interventions and investments for non-formal education channels. These should be designed in consultation with NGOs, churches, community groups, and other relevant organizations. The plan should identify investment requirements for this component over a four year time horizon; (i) formulation of a job description for a permanent EMA Training and Education Officer; (j) provision of input into the design of job descriptions of agency staff and Terms of Reference for TA advisers to ensure that all of they highlight the opportunities for on-the-job training; and (k) preparation of a report describing the above. Budget: US$70,000 Note: Provision has been made for an international TA adviser (two months) and a local advisor (six months).
 98 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - DRAFT TERMS OF REFERENCE's Alternative Mediation Study Background: Most of the judicial mechanisms in Trinidad and Tobago are currently backlogged with cases. This has prompted the government to look into different mechanisms for settling disputes which might relate to environmental issues. It is expected that, to some degree, the new Environmental Commission will provide one mechanism for dealing with disputes that are of a highly contentious nature. It is recognized, however, that other complementary mechanisms may be required for less contentious cases. Purpose: The primary purpose of this exercise is to identify potential alternative dispute resolution mechanisms that can improve the overall cost-effectiveness of resolving environment-related disputes. These mechanisms should be capable of shortening the overall process of dispute resolution, and decrease the load on other parts of the country's judiciary. Implementation: July 1995; started by MoPaD and to be completed by the EMA Legal Unit. Tasks: This activity would focus on research of secondary information sources; consultation; analysis of findings; and, generation of a report. Specifically: (a) review existing legislative and other relevant documents to identify: (i) any relevant examples for alternative mediation; and, (ii) any potential constraints to alternative mediation; (b) preparation and circulation of an issues paper identifying potential alternative mediation mechanisms, along with some of their pros and cons; (c) consultation with relevant agencies inside and outside the government sector regarding the feasibility of various mechanisms; (d) analysis of the feasibility of various mediation alternatives based on consultations and other relevant research; 18. Indicative and subject to change.
 99 ANNEX H Alternative Mediation Study (continued) (e) formulation of recommendations to government and to the EMA regarding the use of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms; and (f) preparation of a final report summarizing the above, and including options for institutional reforms that may be necessary to implement the recommendations. Budget: US$80,000
 100 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - DRAFT TERMS OF REFERENCE'9 PPP Incentive Study I Background: Economic incentives, based on the polluter pay principle (PPP), provide an opportunity for controlling environmental degradation while also decreasing the costs of achieving target levels of environmental quality. A potential long term role for the EMA is to provide advice relating to the use of such instruments and to oversee the efficient implementation of any such programs. There is currently very limited use of such instruments and very limited awareness of their potential scope for application. Purpose: The primary objective of this exercise is to increase the awareness of policy-makers regarding the potential use of PPP incentives. A secondary objective is to identify areas or sectors in Trinidad and Tobago where the application of such incentives may be most beneficial. Implementation: November 1995, EMA Planning Unit. Tasks: This activity would focus on: consultation; research of secondary information sources; generation of a report; and, presentation of findings in a workshop consisting of senior policy-makers and government functionaries. Specifically, the tasks include: (a) preparation and circulation of a brief background paper describing the PPP and various types of incentive mechanisms (e.g., strict regulatory, taxes and charges, market creation, etc.); (b) consultation with government agencies, the private sector, and NGOs regarding the potential use of such mechanisms; (c) review of existing activities in Trinidad and Tobago to select simple case studies to show how such incentives are currently being applied, or might be applied; (d) preparation and presentation of an interim report (based on above tasks) as a background paper for a workshop of senior policy-makers and others; 19. Indicative and subject to change.
 101 ANNEX H (e) facilitation of a one-day meeting or workshop relating to the potential use of PPP incentives; (f) formulation of recommendations relating to the use of incentives, including: sectors/areas with greatest potential; institutional requirements; risks; and, potential implementation schedule; and (g) preparation of final report. Budget: US$60,000
 102 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - DRAFI TERMS OF REFERENCE20 PPP Incentive Study H Background: Economic incentives, based on the polluter pay principle (PPP), provide an opportunity for controlling environmental degradation while also decreasing the costs of achieving target levels of environmental quality. A potential long term role of the EMA is to provide advice relating to the use of such instruments and to oversee the efficient implementation of any such programs. There is currently limited use of such instruments and limited awareness of their potential scope for application. Purpose: The primary objective of this exercise is to design - as an example - an economic incentive mechanism that might reduce environmental damage in a high priority area. A secondary objective is to identify a feasible institutional arrangement for implementing such incentives, and to increase awareness regarding the institutional issues associated with implementing such incentives. Implementation: April 1996, EMA Planning Unit. TAsks: The tasks associated with this activity focus on: consultation; research of secondary information sources; generation of a report; and, presentation of findings in a workshop consisting of senior policy-makers and government functionaries. Specifically, the tasks include: (a) review of findings of Incentive Study I; (b) selection of a high priority area in which an economic incentive mechanism may be applied; (c) selection of a methodology for designing such a mechanism; (d) conduct a review of secondary sources to gather information necessary for the design of this mechanism; (e) apply the methodology to the gathered information to develop a case study of how the mechanism may be applied in Trinidad and Tobago; 20. Indicative and subject to change.
 103 ANNEX H PPP Incentive Study II (Continued) (f) preparation of a brief background paper summarizing the case study and outlining the institutional issues in implementing such a system; (g) circulation of the paper as the background document for a workshop of senior policy-makers and others; (h) facilitation of a one-day meeting or workshop relating to the institutional issues associated with implementing such incentives; (i) formulation of recommendations relating to the use of incentives, including: sectors/areas with greatest potential; institutional requirements; risks; and, potential implementation schedule; and (j) preparation of final report. Budget: US$60,000
 104 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - DRAFT TERMS OF REFERENCE2' Innovative Finance Mechanism Study Background: Most of the polluter-pay types of incentives to be addressed in other studies are expected to provide a direct incentive for sound environmental management. The revenue impact of many of these incentives is minimal. Other mechanisms for financing environmental institutions are, however, available, but may have little impact on environmental quality. Purpose: The primary purpose is to identify and assess long term options for bolstering the financial autonomy of the EMA. A secondary purpose is to identify the institutional requirements for implementing the preferred options. Implementation: January, 1996; EMA Planning Unit. TIsks: The tasks associated with this activity focus on: research of secondary information sources; consultation; analysis of findings; and, generation of a report. Specifically, the tasks include: (a) review existing mechanisms to identify any relevant examples for innovative financing schemes, including both involuntary levies on existing fees (such as premia on postage stamps) and voluntary levies (such as lottery or gaming proceeds); (b) collection of this material to be drawn from existing Trinidad and Tobago agencies (where relevant) or from external sources; (c) consultation with relevant agencies inside and outside of government regarding the feasibility of various mechanisms; (d) analysis of the feasibility of the various alternatives based on consultations and any other relevant research; (e) formulation of recommendations to GoRTT and to the EMA Board regarding the use of innovative finance mechanisms; and (f) preparation of a final report summarizing the above, and including options for institutional reforms that may be necessary to implement the recommendations. Budget: US$40,000 21. Indicative and subject to change.
 105 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - DRAFT TERMS OF REFERENCE22 Natural Resource & Envirommental Accounting (NREA) Study Background: There is growing awareness that conventional methods of growth accounting - GDP and GNP - do not adequately address issues relating to environmental degradation such as the depletion of resource stocks and the declining quality of non-marketed environmental goods and services. Techniques of Natural Resource and Environmental Accounting have been developed, and are currently being implemented by UN countries on an experimental basis. These techniques provide an important tool for providing policy makers with information that can assist in identifying the most cost-effective environmental management interventions. Purpose: The primary objective of this study is to identify environmental information needs and appropriate environmental accounting methodologies for assisting in cost-effective planning. A secondary objective is to generate a case study based on existing information that can be used to identify the data requirements and to serve as an educational tool for describing the linkages between economic activity and environmental quality. Implementation: January, 1996; EMA Planning Unit. 'Isks: The tasks associated with this activity focus on: consultation; research of secondary information sources; generation of a report; and, presentation of findings in a workshop consisting of senior policy-makers and government functionaries. Specifically, the tasks include: (a) review of environmental and economic information sources, and consultation with government officials and others associated with economic and environmental planning; (b) selection of one or more NREA methodologies that may be applied in a case study, and sector(s), region(s) and/or time period(s) to which the methodology may be applied; (c) preparation of a case study based on these selections; (d) preparation of a brief background paper summarizing the case study and outlining the implications and potential applications of the work; 22. Indicative and subject to change.
 106 ANNEX H Natural Resource & Environmental Accounting Study (Continued) (e) circulation of the paper as the background document for a workshop of senior policy-makers and others; (f) facilitation of a one-day meeting or workshop relating to natural resource and environmental accounting; (g) formulation of recommendations relating to the use of NREA including: sectors/areas with greatest priority; information requirements; institutional requirements (including the role of the EMA); potential implementation schedule; and, (h) preparation of final report. Budget: US$100,000
 107 ANNEX H TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROPOSED STUDIES - TERMS OF REFERENCE23 Mid-term Evaluation Report Background: The Environmental Management Project includes a significant number of initiatives that involve establishing, reforming or strengthening institutions on the basis of ongoing consultations and studies. Although the original project design will accommodate many potential contingencies, a formal review of performance, as well as future options, will facilitate implementation of the latter phases of the project. This is particularly critical because capacity development may well constrain future plans, and some mechanism is therefore required to ensure that any implementation bottlenecks are addressed effectively. The mid-term review will require that an independent arms-length report be prepared for review by the Govemment and the Bank. Purpose: The report is an integral part of the mid-term review process. The mid-term review has the following objectives: (a) monitoring and assessment of the implementation phase and of the effectiveness of MoPaD during this phase; (b) assessment of the capacity of the EMA and the Participating Agencies in fulfilling their environmental management functions; (c) review of original work program with a view to identifying implementation bottlenecks and appropriate strategic revisions to project design; and (d) review of specific work components to assess specific modifications to future project components (especially as these relate to training and supplementary institutional strengthening.) Implementation: not later than June 1997; EMA Planning Unit with input from MoPaD. lhsks: The tasks associated with this activity focus on: consultation; review of all project outputs; and, preparation of recommendations. It will be carried out in two phases: Phase I involves a brief delineation of monitoring criteria; and, Phase II involves the actual review and assessment. The specific tasks include: Phase I (a) consultation with the EMA and MoPaD to confirm monitoring and review criteria; 23. Indicative and subject to change.
 108 ANNEX H Mid-term Evaluation Report (continued) (b) preparation of an information request to be submitted to all relevant participating agencies; Phase *1 (c) conduct of interviews with project staff and consultants, after allowing three to six months response time to the information request; (d) assessment of the current level of training and institutional capacity within the environmental management agency and participating agencies given: (i) the observations and recommendations of the training study; (ii) the priority areas identified under the NEAP; and (iii) the institutional recommendations in the rationalization study; (e) assessment of the effectiveness of project activities relating to the following individual project components: (i) consensus building; (ii) public awareness campaign; (iii) operations manuals; (iv) international treaty reporting; (v) complaints handling; (vi) interim compliance monitoring; (vii) state-of-environment reporting; (viii) curriculum development; (ix) non-formal environmental education; (x) EIA reviews; and, (xi) planning studies; (f) provision of recommendations relating to adjustments of future scheduled activities, given current levels of training and the progress achieved in above activities; (g) identification of additional activities, funding requirements and funding opportunities that may beneficially complement the project. This task should also include a description of other environmental projects initiated by GoRlT during the period under evaluation; and (h) preparation of a 'mid-term evaluation' report for review by Government and the Bank. Budget: US$100,000

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Environmental Management Project is to build effective institutional capacity to plan and implement sound environmental management. Further objectives are to complete a national environmental action plan (NEAP), support a priority work program which will strengthen the legal and regulatory framework, and implement measures for improved environmental management consistent with the findings of the NEAP. The project will provide for: 1) the purchase of computer hardware and software and other office equipment and vehichles; 2) about 150 person-months of international and local consultants who will prepare a NEAP, provide advice on policy, legal and technical matters, and undertake studies on priority areas; 3) training workshops, seminars, public awareness, curriculum development and environmental education; 4) the cost of incremental salaries for staff contracted, support for the Environmental Management Authority, and the incremental costs associated with support of the participating agencies (NGO's, private sector agencies, etc.); and 5) operational and overhead materials and supplies for the project.
